courseTitle: Foundations of Machine Learning for Artists and Designers
overview:
The course should explore how creative professionals can use ML tools to enhance digital art, generate content, and build interactive experiences.
Cover ML concepts like classification, clustering, style transfer, and GANs in an intuitive, visual way — no coding required.
Include hands-on practice using RunwayML, Teachable Machine, and DALL·E.
Explain how ML models are trained using data, how prompts guide outputs, and how bias affects results.
Design assignments where learners apply models to personal artwork or design portfolios.
Each module should have at least one tool demo, a quiz, and a creative task.
Conclude with a capstone project using generative or interactive AI art.
audience: Non-technical creatives, artists, and design students.

modules.moduleName: Module 1: Introduction to Machine Learning for Creatives
modules.description: This module introduces fundamental ML concepts and their relevance to creative fields. Students will understand the basic terminology and potential applications of ML in art and design.

submodules.name: Submodule 1.1: What is Machine Learning?
submodules.description: Defining machine learning, its types (supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement), and its difference from traditional programming.
submodules.videoLecture: Introduction to Machine Learning: A Creative Perspective
submodules.summary: Machine learning enables computers to learn from data without explicit programming.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a type of machine learning?

submodules.name: Submodule 1.2: Applications of ML in Art and Design
submodules.description: Exploring diverse applications like generative art, style transfer, interactive installations, and personalized design.
submodules.summary: ML empowers artists and designers with new tools for creation and interaction.

quiz.question: Which of these is an example of ML in art?

submodules.name: Submodule 1.3: Introduction to Datasets
submodules.description: Understanding the role of data in ML, different types of datasets, and data collection methods relevant to creative projects.
submodules.summary: Datasets are crucial for training ML models and influencing their outputs.

quiz.question: What is the primary role of a dataset in machine learning?

modules.assignment: Brainstorm three potential ML applications for your own artistic or design practice.

modules.description: This module provides a hands-on introduction to RunwayML, a no-code platform for using and training machine learning models. Students will learn how to navigate the interface and run pre-trained models.

submodules.name: Submodule 2.1: Navigating the RunwayML Interface
submodules.description: A guided tour of the RunwayML interface, explaining key features and functionalities.
submodules.summary: RunwayML offers a user-friendly interface for exploring and using ML models.

quiz.question: What is the primary purpose of RunwayML?

submodules.name: Submodule 2.2: Running Pre-trained Models in RunwayML
submodules.description: Step-by-step instructions on how to run pre-trained models for image generation, style transfer, and object detection.
submodules.summary: RunwayML allows easy access to and use of various pre-trained ML models.

quiz.question: Which of the following tasks can be performed using pre-trained models in RunwayML?

submodules.name: Submodule 2.3: Exploring Different Model Categories
submodules.description: Overview of different model categories available in RunwayML, such as image-to-image translation, text generation, and pose estimation.
submodules.summary: RunwayML offers a diverse range of model categories for various creative applications.

quiz.question: Which of these is a model category available in RunwayML?

modules.assignment: Experiment with three different pre-trained models in RunwayML and document your findings.

modules.moduleName: Module 3: Teachable Machine: Training Your Own Models
modules.description: This module introduces Teachable Machine, a tool for training custom image, audio, and pose-based ML models without coding. Students will learn how to collect data, train models, and export them for use in other applications.

submodules.name: Submodule 3.1: Introduction to Teachable Machine
submodules.description: Overview of Teachable Machine's features and capabilities for creating custom ML models.
submodules.summary: Teachable Machine simplifies the process of training custom ML models.

quiz.question: What type of data can Teachable Machine use to train models?

submodules.name: Submodule 3.2: Collecting and Preparing Training Data
submodules.description: Best practices for collecting and preparing data for training effective ML models in Teachable Machine.
submodules.videoLecture: Collecting Training Data for Teachable Machine
submodules.summary: High-quality training data is essential for building accurate ML models.

quiz.question: Why is it important to have diverse training data?
options: To make the model more accurate
quiz.answer: To make the model more accurate

submodules.name: Submodule 3.3: Training and Evaluating Models
submodules.description: Step-by-step guide on training models in Teachable Machine and evaluating their performance.
submodules.videoLecture: Training and Evaluating Models in Teachable Machine
submodules.summary: Teachable Machine provides tools for training and evaluating model accuracy.

quiz.question: What does 'training' a model mean?
options: Showing it examples to learn from
quiz.answer: Showing it examples to learn from

submodules.name: Submodule 3.4: Exporting and Using Trained Models
submodules.description: Instructions on how to export trained models from Teachable Machine and use them in web applications or other creative projects.
submodules.videoLecture: Exporting and Using Models from Teachable Machine
submodules.summary: Trained models can be exported and integrated into various creative projects.

quiz.question: What can you do with an exported model from Teachable Machine?
options: Use it in a web application
quiz.answer: Use it in a web application

modules.assignment: Train a custom image classification model using Teachable Machine to recognize different types of artwork or design styles.

modules.moduleName: Module 4: Generative AI with DALL·E and Prompt Engineering
modules.description: This module explores the use of DALL·E and other text-to-image models for generative art. Students will learn how to write effective prompts to guide the AI and generate desired outputs.

submodules.name: Submodule 4.1: Introduction to DALL·E and Text-to-Image Models
submodules.description: Overview of DALL·E and other text-to-image models, explaining their capabilities and limitations.
submodules.videoLecture: Introduction to DALL·E and Text-to-Image Models
submodules.summary: DALL·E generates images from textual descriptions, opening new creative possibilities.

quiz.question: What is the primary input for DALL·E?

submodules.name: Submodule 4.2: The Art of Prompt Engineering
submodules.description: Techniques for writing effective prompts to guide text-to-image models and achieve desired artistic results.
submodules.summary: Crafting precise prompts is crucial for controlling the output of generative AI models.

quiz.question: What is 'prompt engineering'?
options: Writing effective text prompts for AI
quiz.answer: Writing effective text prompts for AI

submodules.name: Submodule 4.3: Exploring Different Prompting Strategies
submodules.description: Experimenting with different prompting strategies, such as using keywords, artistic styles, and specific details to influence the generated images.
submodules.summary: Different prompting strategies can lead to diverse and creative outputs.

quiz.question: Which of the following can be used in a prompt to influence the generated image?

submodules.name: Submodule 4.4: Iterating and Refining Generated Images
submodules.description: Techniques for iterating on generated images, refining prompts, and using post-processing tools to achieve desired results.
submodules.videoLecture: Iterating and Refining Images with DALL·E
submodules.summary: Iterative refinement is key to achieving desired results with generative AI.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of iterating on generated images?

modules.assignment: Create a series of images using DALL·E, experimenting with different prompts and artistic styles.

modules.moduleName: Module 5: Understanding Bias and Ethical Considerations
modules.description: This module addresses the ethical implications of using ML in creative contexts, focusing on bias in datasets and models, and responsible AI practices.

submodules.name: Submodule 5.1: Identifying Bias in Datasets
submodules.description: Understanding how bias can creep into datasets and affect the outputs of ML models.
submodules.summary: Biased datasets can lead to unfair or discriminatory outcomes.

quiz.question: What is a potential consequence of using a biased dataset?

submodules.name: Submodule 5.2: Mitigating Bias in ML Models
submodules.description: Techniques for mitigating bias in ML models, such as data augmentation, re-weighting, and fairness-aware algorithms.
submodules.summary: Various techniques can be used to reduce bias in ML models.

quiz.question: Which of the following is a technique for mitigating bias in ML models?

submodules.name: Submodule 5.3: Ethical Considerations for Creative AI
submodules.description: Exploring ethical considerations related to the use of AI in creative contexts, such as copyright, ownership, and the impact on human artists.
submodules.summary: Ethical considerations are crucial when using AI in creative endeavors.

quiz.question: What is an ethical consideration when using AI in creative contexts?

submodules.name: Submodule 5.4: Responsible AI Practices
submodules.description: Promoting responsible AI practices, such as transparency, accountability, and fairness, in creative projects.
submodules.summary: Transparency, accountability, and fairness are key to responsible AI practices.

quiz.question: What is a key element of responsible AI practices?

modules.assignment: Write a short essay discussing the ethical implications of using AI to generate art, considering issues such as copyright and bias.

modules.moduleName: Module 6: Advanced ML Techniques for Creative Applications
modules.description: This module delves into more advanced ML techniques, such as style transfer and GANs, and explores their potential for creating innovative art and design.

submodules.name: Submodule 6.1: Deep Dive into Style Transfer
submodules.description: Exploring the concept of style transfer, its underlying algorithms, and its applications in art and design.
submodules.summary: Style transfer allows transferring the style of one image to another.

quiz.question: What does style transfer allow you to do?
options: Transfer the style of one image to another
quiz.answer: Transfer the style of one image to another

submodules.name: Submodule 6.2: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for Art
submodules.description: Introduction to GANs, their architecture, and their use in generating realistic and creative images.
submodules.summary: GANs can generate realistic and creative images through adversarial training.

quiz.question: What are GANs used for?

submodules.name: Submodule 6.3: Creating Interactive AI Art Installations
submodules.description: Exploring the use of ML models to create interactive art installations that respond to user input and generate dynamic visual experiences.
submodules.summary: ML models can be used to create interactive and dynamic art installations.

quiz.question: What can ML models be used for in interactive art installations?

submodules.name: Submodule 6.4: Future Trends in AI and Creativity
submodules.description: Discussing emerging trends in AI and their potential impact on the future of art and design.
submodules.videoLecture: Future Trends in AI and Creativity
submodules.summary: AI is rapidly evolving and will continue to transform the creative landscape.

quiz.question: What is a likely future trend in AI and creativity?
options: AI becoming more integrated into creative workflows
quiz.answer: AI becoming more integrated into creative workflows

modules.assignment: Experiment with style transfer or GANs to create a unique piece of AI-generated art.

capstoneProject.title: Generative AI Art Portfolio
capstoneProject.description: Create a portfolio of AI-generated artwork or interactive design projects, showcasing your understanding of ML concepts and your creative use of AI tools. The portfolio should demonstrate your ability to use prompts effectively, address ethical considerations, and create visually compelling and innovative work.
